items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
This is an opportunity for members of the public to address the Board concerning issues not listed on the agenda.
	 
The Board welcomes this opportunity to hear from the public and has established a policy for the public's participation in board meetings, which is outlined in BP 2345. This policy states that:
	 
No member of the public may speak without being recognized by the President of the Board.
Each speaker will be allowed a maximum of three minutes per topic. Thirty minutes shall be the maximum time allotment for public speakers on any one subject regardless of the number of speakers at any one Board meeting. At the discretion of a majority of the Board, these time limits may be extended.
The Board recognizes the need to encourage public participation but also recognizes the need to preserve order and the proper functioning of the meeting. Citizens addressing the Board at meetings shall therefore conduct themselves at all times in a manner appropriate to the setting.

items.item_details:
1. Evergreen Valley College Adjunct Faculty
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the AFT 6157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Article 9.13 submission and recommendation:
Article 9.13 ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING - Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 9.13 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the faculty personnel action as submitted.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $86,000 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of August 10, 2015 through September 9, 2015 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details:
Board Policy 7080.203 defines Class III Records as, including but not limited to, detailed records relating to:  records basic to an audit, including those relating to attendance, average daily attendance, or a business or financial transaction (purchase orders, invoices, warrants, ledger sheets, canceled checks and stubs, student body and cafeteria records, etc.), and detailed records used in the preparation of any other report.
	 
Board Policy 7080.204 states that Class III Records basic to an audit shall not be destroyed until after the third July 1st succeeding the completion of the audit required by Education Code 84040 or of any other legally required audit, or after the ending date of any retention period required by any agency other than the State of California, whichever date is later.
	 
The Bookstores have the following Class III Records that meet the criteria for destruction:
	 
Parking Permit Logs through FY 2010-11
Online Order Logs through FY 2010-11
Month-end / Sales Reports through FY 2010-11
Paid/Returned Checks through FY 2010-11
Accounts Payable / Receivable Records through FY 2010-11
Financial Statements through FY 2010-11
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the destruction of records listed per Section 7080.203 of the Retention and Destruction of Records under Board Policies.

items.item_details: On August 25, 2015, the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors approved a contract with Wells Fargo Bank to provide operational banking services through October 31, 2020 for the County, schools, and special districts.  This approval was a result of an RFP published by Santa Clara County because the current contract with Bank of America had been in place for the limit of five (5) years.  The County has notified the District that this transition will take place effective December 1, 2015.  Accordingly, the purpose of this item is for the Board of Trustees to formally ratify the District's change in banks from Bank of America to Wells Fargo.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the transfer of operational banking services from Bank of America to Wells Fargo.
items.item_text: Operational Banking Services
items.item_text_raw: 12. Operational Banking Services

items.item_details:
Per California Public Contract Code Section 20652, "the governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract, lease, requisition or purchase order ... (to) purchase materials, supplies, equipment ... and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency is authorized by law to make the lease or purchase." The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of a negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation agency.
	 
Therefore, when considering the best interest for the District, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees award a piggybackable contract between the Foundation for California Community Colleges (Foundation) and KI without the need to further advertise for bids on an already competitively bid contract. The Foundation is the official foundation supporting the Board of Governors, Chancellor's Office, and the entire California Community College system.
	 
Attached are an affidavit of publication, Foundation's Board action item (September 26, 2013) approving the award to KI under RFP 13-002 and a three year contract effective 10/01/2013 to 09/30/2016, with an option to extend the term for two additional one year terms, upon mutual consent.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to 'piggyback' on a contract with Krueger International (KI) Furniture.

ENGR 500:  Introduction to Engineering
ENGR 502:  Basic Math Applications in Engineering
SG 500:  Introduction to Surveying & Geomatics
SG 502:  Basic Math Application in Surveying and Geomatics

items.item_details:
ACCJC Accreditation Standard IA.1. The mission describes the institutionâs broad educational purposes, its intended student population, the types of degrees and other credentials it offers, and its commitment to student learning and student achievement.
	 
During the writing of the self-evaluation for EVC, standard I chair and writers noted that the existing campus mission did not include a listing of degrees and credentials. Since adding this language facilitated compliance with standard IA.1. and did not change the overall feel of the mission, the drafted language has followed college processes for approval as outlined below:
	 
5/15/15 College Accreditation Steering Committee
	 
6/16/15 and 7/21/15 Integrated Planning summer retreats - included members of the following committees/constituencies:
	 
Institutional Effectiveness, Student Success, Academic Senate, Facilities and Safety, Curriculum, Budget, SLO Sub-committee, EVC student, Academic Affairs, Administrative Services, District Office (IESS)
	 
8/27/15 College-Wide Professional Development Day - general session
	 
9/14/15 and 9/28/15 College Council approval
	 
Updated EVC Mission Statement
	 
With equity, opportunity and social justice as our guiding principles, Evergreen Valley Collegeâs mission is to empower and prepare students from diverse backgrounds to succeed academically and to be civically responsible global citizens.
	 
We meet our mission through a wide spectrum of educational experiences, flexible methodologies, and support services for our students. We offer associate degrees, associate degree for transfer, certificates, career technical education, transfer coursework, and basic skills education.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the updated Evergreen Valley College Mission Statement.
items.item_text: Evergreen Valley College Mission Statement
items.item_text_raw: 15. Evergreen Valley College Mission Statement

items.item_details:
The sponsorship monies are to cover production and operational expenses incurred by Evergreen Valley College for the Silicon Valley Code Camp held on October 3 and 4, 2015.
	 
Over 2,500 attendees were expected to attend Silicon Valley Code Camp hosted at Evergreen Valley College on Oct 3 and 4, 2015.  Participants were comprised of students 5-18 years old from across the Bay Area region and were able to learn from Engineers. 
	 
Many colleges are Minority Serving Institutions (MSI), Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI), as well as Asian American, Native American, Pacific Islander-Serving Institutions (AA/NA/PI SI's). These underrepresented groups benefit immensely from this event. Contributions are a joint collaboration from ICT/DM Interior Bay Deputy Sector Navigator Sandy Jones & ICT/DM South West Region Deputy Sector Navigator Olivia Davalos.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept sponosorship from Deputy Sector Navigator for Information Communication Technology: Doing What Matters (Chancellor's Office) in the amount of $27,500 for Silicon Valley Code Camp held at Evergreen Valley College October 3 and 4, 2015.
items.item_text: Acceptance of Sponsorship for Silicon Valley Code Camp at Evergreen Valley College

items.item_details:
Evergreen Valley College will participate in the East Side Alliance Career Pathways Initiative in cooperation with other consortium partners to design and implement a dual/concurrent enrollment program for East Side students.
	 
General Agreements
Evergreen Valley College will:
Collaborate with the East Side Union High School District to adapt and develop rigorous curriculum, participate in training and staff development, and conduct joint outreach and marketing to inform and recruit low income, underrepresented, and special population students into high skill, high wage careers in targeted industry sectors.
Collaborate jointly with East Side and industry and community partners to align rigorous college coursework with relevant technical skills and workplace competencies, as defined by industry, and provide support for students to complete the pathway and transition to employment.
Provide guidance in the development of a dual credit/concurrent enrollment program in identified pathway sectors in the Career Pathways Trust application.
	 
Specific Requirements
Evergreen Valley College will:
Provide faculty liaison(s) to focus on design, development, and planning of dual credit/concurrent enrollment program and curriculum alignment for Vehicle Technology and Auto Pathways.
Provide faculty/staff to participate in cohort and team building activities and attend collaboration meetings and staff training for identified industry sectors.
Participate in reporting and evaluation required by the East Side Alliance Consortium and the California Department of Education.
Provide in-kind or other match of $133,800 to support above activities.

items.item_details:
The U.S. Department of Education under the Title V Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program has awarded San Jose City College a five-year grant totaling $3,248,296.00
	 
The principal goal of the Cultivamos Excelencia Project is to motivate and retain Hispanic and other high-need students to complete a degree at a research university.  By working together, SJCC and University of California-Santa Cruz will use a combination of tutoring, mentoring, research skills instruction, transfer advising and, perhaps most important, participation in undergraduate research experiences to encourage self-efficacy, skill development and motivation to complete their bachelor degrees on time and with highly honed set of analytical and writing skills.  By developing and delivering Research Methods courses for transfer credit and summer undergraduate research experiences that will give them university credit for community college tuition, the project will give students who might not think they can succeed at a research university a head start at that university.
	           
To achieve this goal, the Project has developed the following eight objectives:
ÂˇThe percentage of two-year college Hispanic students transferring will increase from 33% to 43% by the end of the grant period.
90% of community college students in the program will maintain a 3.2 or higher GPA.
90% of program students who transfer to the university will maintain a 2.8 or higher GPA
The percentage of program students who transfer and are retained from Fall semester to Fall semester will increase from 91% to 95%.   (Starting year 3 through year 5)
The time-to-graduation for students in the project from their first enrollment at SJCC to graduation at UCSC will decrease by one year.
The number of Hispanic transfer students graduating within 6 years of their initial enrollment will increase from 77% to 80%.
Eighteen Programs, or 75% of Cultivamos Excelencia Project programs, will continue working relationships in some form at the end of the grant period among faculty at the two institutions.
Within five years, there will be a sustainability commitment by both institutions to continue the program.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept Year 1 grant funds awarded to San Jose City College for the grant period effective October 1, 2015 through September 30, 2015 in the amount of $649,499.00 from the U.S. Department of Education, Title V Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program.
items.item_text: Acceptance of Grant Funds - San Jose City College
items.item_text_raw: 18. Acceptance of Grant Funds - San Jose City College

items.item_details:
The premise of this agreement is for current course work at both The Valley Foundation School of Nursing (TVSON) at San Jose State University and Evergreen Valley College (EVC) to provide a more streamlined process for EVC Nursing Students to have upward mobility to obtain a BS Degree in Nursing (BSN).
	 
San Jose State University Research Foundation (SJSURF), in collaboration with Evergreen Valley College, wishes to meet the needs of EVC Associate Degree in Nursing (ADN) students by administering a concurrent BSN program to selected EVC ADN Nursing Students.  This will include (but not limited to) providing TVSON Instructors and Administrative services to EVC Administration and EVC ADN Students in management of the BSN Coursework.  Evergreen Valley College has resources to collaborate with San Jose State University Research Foundation in support of the use of Project Coordinators, Program Managers and Administration.  
	 
SJSURF and EVC will collaborate in the development of upward mobility for EVC Nursing Students.  Funding not to exceed $106,794 will be provided by a grant awarded to EVC by the Office of Statewide Health Planning & Development Song-Brown Health Care Workforce Training Program.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the agreement between Evergreen Valley College and The Valley Foundation School of Nursing (TVSON) at San Jose State University.
items.item_text: Agreement between Evergreen Valley College and The Valley Foundation School of Nursing (TVSON) at San Jose State University
items.item_text_raw: 19. Agreement between Evergreen Valley College and The Valley Foundation School of Nursing (TVSON) at San Jose State University

items.item_details:
SACNAS is a society of students and professionals dedicated to advancing Hispanics and Native Americans in science.  They are open to students from any ethnic/cultural background who want to actively prepare students and promote involvement in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).
	 
SACNAS members are involved in outreach at local middle schools and high schools. Each year since its founding in 2006 the EVC SACNAS chapter organizes and coordinates a STEM conference at the college. This past year over 150 students spent the day learning about careers and areas of studies in STEM. Additionally, eight members have been involved in the NASA Arduino Project over the summer. These members have presented their creative designs to a group of scientists at NASA Moffett Field and to the EVC community.
	 
The four student SACNAS officers, Mara Leandro, Edith Martinez, Benjamin Beiza, and Alma Acosta, as well as their chaperone, Professor Jose Cabrera from SJCC, plan to attend the SACNAS conference in Washington D.C. October 29 through October 31, 2015.  The conference will focus on diversity in STEM by fostering interdisciplinary, interactive, and transformative collaboration among scientists.
	 
Per AP 6300.9, it is requested that the Board of Trustees approve student travel to Washington, D.C.  SACNAS has received funding commitments that will provide the necessary funds for the trip.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve student travel to the SACNAS Conference in Washington, D.C.
items.item_text: Student Travel to Washington, D.C. for SACNAS Conference
items.item_text_raw: 20. Student Travel to Washington, D.C. for SACNAS Conference

items.item_details:
On November 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to C. Overaa & Company in the amount of $11,347,704 to provide construction services for the Automotive Technology Building Project at Evergreen Valley College.   
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 008 includes the addition of exterior structural concrete pads to support chemical and transmission storage units, modifications to vehicle exhaust hose reel connection points as required by Division of the State Architect (DSA), storm drainage modifications to existing lines at Cedro building, added structural clips attachments for curtainwall and storefront systems, and removal of unsuitable soils which include organic and lime-treated material.
	 
C. Overaa & Company submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the Agenda attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                 $11,347,704
Previous Approved Changes                            $  1,557,815
Change Order No. 008                                     $       72,318   
Total Contract and Changes                             $12,977,837
	 
The net change to C. Overaa & Company's contract as a result of all changes issued is $1,630,133, which equates to 14.37% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 008 in the amount of $72,318 to C. Overaa & Company for the Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On November 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to C. Overaa & Company in the amount of $11,347,704 to provide construction services for the Automotive Technology Building Project at Evergreen Valley College.   
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 009 is the result of the District’s request to competitively bid, procure and install shop equipment included in the Group-1 Furniture, Fixtures & Equipment (FF&E) package, and includes additional Electrical, Plumbing and Structural modifications to complete the purchase and installation of the Group-1 Furniture, Fixtures & Equipment (FF&E) items which were not chosen by the end user prior to the release of the previous FF&E Change Order #006.  This Change Order also includes additional structural bracing and painting for vehicle exhaust reels as a result of Division of the State Architect review.  The change cost breakdown equates to 30% material and 70% installation.
	 
Including the Group-1 FF&E items in C. Overaa & Company’s contract will benefit the project because many of C. Overaa & Company’s subcontractors will be performing the required work, will eliminate the added time and expense of an additional procurement process, which would likely result in added cost due to the current bid market and will include the procurement and installation into C. Overaa & Company’s project warranty.  Legal counsel has reviewed this change; while the cumulative amount for change orders for this project now exceeds ten percent he has affirmed it is not applicable for this contract.  Changing the funding source from owner furnished to contractor supplied does not require separate bidding due to the flexibility in the lease leaseback delivery method since the scope had always been planned in the project.  The list of equipment remained a work in progress as the project started. 
	 
C. Overaa & Company submitted written pricing proposals for these changes that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposal has been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                 $11,347,704
Previous Approved Changes                            $  1,630,133
Change Order No. 009                                     $     181,030   
Total Contract and Changes                             $13,158,867
	 
The net change to C. Overaa & Company's contract as a result of all changes issued is $1,811,163, which equates to 15.96% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 009 in the amount of $181,030 to C. Overaa & Company for the Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 at Evergreen Valley College.

Utilizing the public bidding process, on June 25, 2014 the Selection Committee (which included the Furniture Consultant, District Purchasing, and College Deans) evaluated and approved the proposed alternate product to be supplied by the low bidder, Sedia Systems Inc. and issued an Independent Contract Agreement.  Since the Agreement and Purchase Order were executed the South Campus Development Construction Contractor notified the Construction Manager that due to sequencing and the Construction Schedule they cannot accommodate delivery and/or installation of the fixed table furniture before mid-December. 
	 
Sedia Systems Inc. is contracted for the supply and installation of the fixed table furniture in the three (3) tiered lecture rooms of the South Campus Development Project at Evergreen Valley College (EVC).
	 
This change does not affect the cost, scope, or expiration date of the original ICA, only the date that the Contractor shall complete its Work by.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve revision of the Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) to Sedia Systems Inc. to revise the date the “Contractor shall complete its Work by” from November 30th, 2015 to January 30th, 2016 (Section 19 Terms of Agreement).

items.item_details:
As part of the South Campus Development project, the design team engaged a fitness consultant (MediFit) to perform a detailed study of the equipment needs of the Physical Education Department in order to determine; user needs, functionality and performance for use in the new South Campus Development Project, Fitness Center at Evergreen Valley College (EVC).  Detailed equipment specifications were generated and reviewed by the District, MediFit and the District’s furniture, Fixtures and Equipment consultant, KRJ.  The resulting requirements for the new strength equipment were put out for public bid. 
	 
The public bidding process for vendors was conducted between August 26, 2015 and September 16, 2015.  The project was advertised in local papers on August 26, 2015 and September 2, 2015.  In addition, email invitations to Bid were sent to eight (8) vendors, including local commercial vendors and manufacturers’ representatives for the equipment specified by the selection committee.  
	 
Four (4) bids were received at 3:00 pm on September 16, 2015.  A selection committee that included college teaching staff, the fitness consultant, the FF&E consultant and District purchasing evaluated the bid responses.  The selection committee reviewed the bid unit prices and evaluated several proposed alternates in relation to bid specifications.  Based on the selection committee’s evaluation, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees award contracts to the companies and in the not-to-exceed amounts listed below:
	 
Opti-Fit International, Inc.                             $  94,944.19
Precor Commercial Fitness                          $  22,617.19
Total Cost:                                                   $117,561.38
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award the Independent Contractor Agreements, not-to-exceed the amount indicated, to the following strength equipment vendors Opti-Fit International, Inc. ($94,944.19) and Precor Commercial Fitness ($22,617.19) for a total amount of $117,561.38 for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On June 9, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to R.C. Benson & Sons Inc. in the amount of $917,500.00 to provide construction services for the Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 at San Jose City College.
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions; District requested or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 003 is for design changes as well as changes resulting from unforeseen conditions. 
	 
R.C. Benson & Sons Inc. submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                       $    917,500.00
Previous Approved Changes                  $    126,155.00
Change Order No. 003                           $      77,325.00
Total Contract and Changes                   $ 1,120,980.00
	 
The net change to R.C. Benson & Sons Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $203,480.00 which equates to 22.18% of the original contract. Unforseen conditions account for approximately $149,400.00 of the total cost of the changes, or 16.3% against the original contract. This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change and from project savings to date.
	 
	 
Pursuant to Public Contract Code sections 20118.4 and 20659 (applicable to community college districts); a contract may be increased or decreased after the bid is awarded due to changes that might arise during the course of the contract. These changes are limited to the bid limits or to 10 percent of the original contract price whichever is greater. These limits, according to the California Attorney General, "…appear to be inserted to ensure that substantial changes are not made which would, in effect, constitute the making of a new contract."[1] Furthermore, it is in the Attorney General’s view that “… change orders are appropriately contemplated where, during the performances of the contract, unforeseen matters are discovered which require some modification to complete the contract.” 73 Ops.Cal.Atty.Gen. 417 (1990).
	 
The purpose of Sections 20118.4 and 20659 is to allow some flexibility following the award of the bid, and to ensure that substantial changes are not made which would constitute the making of a new contract. In effect, the change order provisions allow districts to negotiate changes to a contract provided the contract is not materially altered by the change order to such an extent that it would create a new project or contract which should be bid separately.  Public bidding of the increased scope of Work would not have produced an advantage to the District, and would produce a net burden and distinct disadvantages to the District. Based on the foregoing, it would be incongruous, futile, and unavailing to publicly bid the increased scope of Work.  
	 
This has undergone District legal counsel review for compliance with Public Contract Code.
		 
[1] 73 Ops.Cal.Atty.Gen 417 (1990) footnote no. 3
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 003 in the amount of $77,325.00 to R.C. Benson & Sons Inc., for the Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 at SJCC.

items.item_details:
It is required by the Division of the State Architect (DSA) to have a DSA-approved inspector to ensure compliance with DSA requirements on the project.  The District issued an RFP for Inspector of Record Services (IOR) for the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center. 
	 
On September 11, 2015 the District received six (6) proposals in response to the RFP.  The proposals were evaluated by a committee including representatives of District Purchasing and Gilbane.  Proposals were evaluated on the criteria of Qualifications and references of the on-site inspector, availability of personnel, position rates & proposed fees, and interviews. 
	 
On September 23, 2015, three (3) selected firms were interviewed by the selection committee.  Gilbane facilitated the interviews.  The interview committee evaluated the selected firms based on best value. Santa Clara Valley Construction Inspections was determined to be the best value proposal in the amount of $85,000 and thus is recommended as IOR for the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center project.
	 
	 
The Best Value Ranking of the bids is as follows:
	 
                Santa Clara Valley Construction Inspections         1
                Eagle Enterprises                                                   2
                DSA School Inspectors, LLC                                  3
                Structure Consultants Group                                  4
                4 Leaf Inc.                                                               5
                TYR                                                                        6
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of a contract in the amount of $85,000 to Santa Clara Valley Construction Inspections, for the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center, #309 located in Milpitas, CA.

items.item_details:
The scope of this Agreement is to provide design service to support the Evergreen Campus Network Upgrade Project.  Scope of design services include:  1) Site fiber optics cabling from each building to the new Main Data Frame (MDF), 2) Intra-building fiber optics cabling in all buildings, 3) Uninterrupted Power Supply (UPS) Upgrade, 4) Data closet HVAC Upgrades, 5) Wireless Access Point (WAP) cabling, and 6) Security Camera cabling.  This project designs the infrastructure upgrades to support the campus wide network upgrade at Evergreen Valley College.
	 
Request for Proposal (RFP) was sent to on-call pool of Mechanical – Electrical – Plumbing (MEP) engineering firms.  The selection committee (ITSS, CTSS, District Purchasing, and Gilbane Building Company) evaluated the proposals for best value to the District.  The committee scored the proposals and selected Salas O’Brien to perform the design service for this project.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of an Agreement (PAA #EVC - 05) in the amount of $212,500.00 to Salas O’Brien, for Design Services, IT and Tech Equipment Project #32702 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
This agenda item is for the purchase of network switches and wired/wireless installation services at Evergreen Valley College. This project is to replace the network switches throughout EVC in order to install a new converged, high-performance, high-capacity data network for computer, wireless, voice, video and device communications for all students, staff, faculty, administrators and guests. The project timeline is to deploy the network switches first in the new AutoTech building this fall, new Main Distribution Facility (MDF) in December-January, and the new South Campus buildings in fall/spring (per construction schedule). The remaining network installations will occur during spring and summer 2016 while the new fiber optics cabling is installed between the new MDF and current buildings. The project quote includes up to 40% of after-hours work so as to minimize disruptions to the classroom. The wireless network will be configured as the network switches are replaced, building by building, and as additional cabling is installed for the Wireless Access Points (WAPs). The goal is to largely complete this project (90%+) before fall 2016 classes begin - however this timeline is directly dependent upon getting the fiber optics cabling, WAP cabling and Building/Intermediate Distribution Facility (BDF/IDF) updates installed in a timely manner. 
	 
This project is a major deliverable of Bond Project #32702 to upgrade the IT and Technology Equipment at EVC. The ICA and network switch purchase is based on RFP # G2010.0099 and pursuant to the Master Agreement with Dasher Technologies approved by the board on 8/26/14 (Measure G-2010 Bond Program).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the purchase of network switches and Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) with Dasher Technologies to configure and deploy at Evergreen Valley College for a total cost of $2,187,408.62.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Network Switch Upgrade and Wireless Configuration at Evergreen Valley College

items.item_details:
On May 12, 2015 the Board approved the purchase of network installation services at San Jose City College (PO# B0012180). After the project was underway, it was discovered that (a) the CDUs for connecting the network switches to the power supplies were unnecessary, (b) the quantities of fiber optics cabling types needed to change per Change Order No. 001, (c) additional installation services would be necessary for completing the networking, wireless, security and physical installation. The existing scope of services did not fully anticipate the resources needed for unexpected hardware issues, compatibility issues with the existing core network, routing and VLAN issues, Aerohive firmware update and minor unforeseen items. 
	The change order items are provided in the attached quote from Dasher Technologies (#518245-002).  
	 
Original PO Amount (PO# B0012180)      $675,224.05
Change Order No. 002 Net Increase        $65,101.36
Total with Change Order No. 002            $740,325.40
	 
	 
The total change order percent increase for PO# B0012180 is 9.64%.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 002 to Dasher Technologies in the amount of $65,101.36 for the San Jose City College Network Upgrade.

items.item_text_raw: 16. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Network Switch Upgrade at San Jose City College - Change Order No. 002

The District also expresses appreciation to the many faculty and staff members, who have created educational events in October that pay tribute to Filipino American History Month 2015.

items.item_details:
This month is designated by Congress as “National Disability Employment Awareness Month.”  The origins of this commemoration began in 1945 when Congress passed Joint Resolution 23 and later updated and expanded the law to a month-long commemoration in 1988 to acknowledge the employment needs and contributions of individuals with all types of disabilities.
		 
More recently, ACR 162 (Senator Beall) was passed by the California State Senate and by the California State Assembly which designates the 2nd week in October of each year as “Disability History Week.”   
		 
Locally, over 2,000 students with disabilities are served by the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District.  As such, it is especially important that our Board acknowledges, celebrates and promotes the history of disabilities and the disability rights movement.
		 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees of the San José-Evergreen Community College District approve a resolution in support of the Disabilities Awareness Month 2015 (October), and recognizes the many students, faculty, staff, administrators and leaders with disabilities that have made numerous contributions of great value to our Colleges/District.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 101315-4 in support of Disabilities Awareness Month

items.item_details:
In 2013, the state’s AB86-mandated process initiated the formation of a regional consortium (the South Bay Consortium for Adult Education - SBCAE) tasked with creating a regional plan to transform services provided to adult learners.  The regional plan must ensure a successful transition of adult learners into either college or into employment. With input from all seven participating districts, as well as approximately 30 community organizations, SBCAE developed a three year plan to address services gaps and to align and expand adult education services within the region.  This regionally supported plan was submitted to the state in March 2015 and subsequently accepted.
	 
In June 2015, AB104 introduced an Adult Education Block Grant (AEBG) that outlines specific requirements that consortia must follow for the implementation of their local plan.  The SBCAE plan covers a range of activities that include curriculum alignment, assessments, bridge programs, transitional student support services, business collaboration partnerships, technology, data sharing/tracking and marketing. 
	 
This presentation provides up to date information on the AEBG implementation process, ongoing faculty and academic senate engagement in the program development and approval process, and a description of the six SJECCD Career Development and College Preparation (CDCP) programs that will improve adult learner transition into postsecondary education and workforce preparation proposed for the 2015-16 fiscal year.
items.item_text: AB 104 - Adult Education Block Grant Implementation
items.item_text_raw: 3. AB 104 - Adult Education Block Grant Implementation

items.item_details:
The Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center (JU21-PSEC) is a unique collaboration between the Milpitas Unified School District (MUSD) and the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) to foster a college-going culture for Milpitas High School students through dual enrollment opportunities, general education, as well as STEM focused educational opportunities for Milpitas residents. 
	 
The joint-use facility Phase I Initial Design Committee and the Phase II Educational Programming Committee is continuing efforts to incorporate requirements outlined in the programming document into the design-build phase and to collaboratively develop a MUSD/SJECCD Fall 2016 Schedule.  
	 
This presentation provides up to date progress on the design build and educational programming activities, provides information on the project timeline (including the Groundbreaking Ceremony scheduled for November 17, 2015), and brings forward a recommendation that the facility name be changed from Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center to Milpitas College Campus.
items.item_text: Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
